Physics.title: Unit 1: Force, Work, Power and Energy

notes.title: Types
points: Contact Forces: Frictional force, Normal reaction force, Tension force.
Non-contact Forces: Gravitational force, Magnetic force, Electrostatic force.

notes.title: Laws
points: First Law (Law of Inertia): An object remains at rest or in uniform motion unless acted upon by an external force.
Second Law: Rate of change of momentum is proportional to applied force (F = ma).
Third Law: For every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction.

formulas.title: Second Law
formulas.explanation: Force = mass * acceleration.

realworld.title: Seatbelts
realworld.description: Seatbelts prevent passengers from continuing forward motion (inertia) when a car stops suddenly.

notes.title: Conservation Principle
points: In an isolated system, the total momentum remains constant.
m1u1 + m2u2 = m1v1 + m2v2.

formulas.title: Momentum
formulas.explanation: Momentum is the product of mass and velocity.

realworld.title: Rocket Propulsion
realworld.description: Exhaust gases pushed backward propel the rocket forward with equal momentum.

notes.title: Definition
points: Work is done when a force applied on a body produces displacement.
Zero Work: When displacement is zero or force is perpendicular to displacement.

formulas.title: Work
formulas.explanation: F=Force, s=Displacement, θ=Angle between Force and Displacement.

realworld.title: Porter carrying load
realworld.description: A porter carrying a load on his head and walking horizontally does zero work against gravity (angle is 90°).

notes.title: Definition
points: Energy is the capacity to do work.
SI Unit: Joule (J).

notes.title: Mechanical Energy
points: Potential Energy (PE): Energy possessed by a body due to its position or configuration.
Kinetic Energy (KE): Energy possessed by a body due to its motion.

formulas.title: Potential Energy
formulas.explanation: Gravitational potential energy at height h.

formulas.title: Kinetic Energy
formulas.explanation: Energy of a moving object.

realworld.title: Dam Water
realworld.description: Water stored at a height in a dam possesses potential energy used to generate electricity.

notes.title: Statement
points: Energy can neither be created nor destroyed, only transformed from one form to another.
Total mechanical energy (PE + KE) of a freely falling body remains constant.

topics.name: Power and Commercial Unit of Energy

notes.title: Power
points: Rate of doing work.
SI Unit: Watt (W) or J/s.
Commercial Unit of Energy: Kilowatt-hour (kWh).

formulas.title: Power
formulas.explanation: Power related to Work and Velocity.

formulas.title: Kilowatt-hour
formulas.explanation: Conversion factor.

realworld.title: Electricity Bill
realworld.description: Household electricity consumption is measured in 'units', where 1 unit = 1 kWh.

notes.title: Laws of Reflection
points: Angle of Incidence = Angle of Reflection (i = r).
Incident ray, Reflected ray and Normal all lie in the same plane.

notes.title: Image Characteristics
points: Virtual and Erect.
Laterally inverted (Left appears Right).
Same size as object.
Distance of image behind mirror = Distance of object in front.

realworld.title: Periscope
realworld.description: Uses two plane mirrors at 45° to see objects above the line of sight (e.g., in submarines).

notes.title: Laws of Refraction
points: Snell's Law: ratio of sine of angle of incidence to sine of angle of refraction is constant (Refractive Index).
Light bends towards normal when moving from rarer to denser medium, and away when moving denser to rarer.

formulas.title: Snell's Law
formulas.explanation: μ = Refractive Index.

formulas.title: Refractive Index (Speed)
formulas.explanation: c = Speed of light in vacuum, v = Speed of light in medium.

realworld.title: Twinkling of Stars
realworld.description: Starlight undergoes continuous refraction through changing atmospheric layers, causing twinkling.

notes.title: Types
points: Convex Lens: Converging lens, thicker at center.
Concave Lens: Diverging lens, thinner at center.

formulas.title: Lens Formula
formulas.explanation: f=focal length, v=image distance, u=object distance.

formulas.title: Magnification
formulas.explanation: Ratio of image height to object height.

realworld.title: Spectacles
realworld.description: Convex lenses correct Hypermetropia (Long-sightedness), Concave lenses correct Myopia (Short-sightedness).

realworld.title: Camera
realworld.description: Uses a convex lens to focus real images onto a film or sensor.

notes.title: Mechanism
points: Sound is produced by vibrating bodies.
Requires a material medium (solid, liquid, gas) for propagation.
Cannot travel through vacuum.

formulas.title: Speed of Sound
formulas.explanation: v = Speed, f = Frequency, λ = Wavelength.

notes.title: Conditions
points: Reflection of sound from a distant obstacle.
Minimum distance for distinct echo in air is approx 17m (since sensation of sound persists for 0.1s).

formulas.title: Echo Distance
formulas.explanation: Distance to obstacle.

realworld.title: SONAR
realworld.description: Sound Navigation And Ranging uses ultrasonic echoes to measure depth of ocean or locate underwater objects.

notes.title: Subjective vs Objective
points: Loudness: Depends on Amplitude. Measured in Decibels (dB).
Pitch: Depends on Frequency (Shrillness).
Quality (Timbre): Depends on Waveform (distinguishes same note from different instruments).

realworld.title: Guitar vs Flute
realworld.description: We can distinguish a guitar and a flute playing the same note due to difference in quality (wave patterns).

notes.title: Uses
points: Frequency > 20,000 Hz.
Used in medical imaging (Ultrasound scan), drilling holes, cleaning parts.

realworld.title: Bats
realworld.description: Bats emit ultrasonic squeaks to navigate and find prey in the dark.

notes.title: Ohm's Law
points: Current flowing through a conductor is directly proportional to potential difference across its ends, provided temperature remains constant.
V ∝ I or V = IR.

formulas.title: Ohm's Law
formulas.explanation: Relation between Voltage, Current, and Resistance.

notes.title: Factors Affecting Resistance
points: Material of conductor.
Length (R ∝ L).
Area of Cross-section (R ∝ 1/A).
Temperature.

notes.title: Combination
points: Series: Total R = R1 + R2 + ... (Current same).
Parallel: 1/R = 1/R1 + 1/R2 + ... (Voltage same).

formulas.title: Resistivity
formulas.explanation: ρ (rho) is specific resistance.

realworld.title: Household Wiring
realworld.description: Appliances in homes are connected in parallel so each operates independently at the same voltage.

formulas.title: Electric Power
formulas.explanation: Rate of electrical energy consumption.

formulas.title: Heating Effect (Joule's Law)
formulas.explanation: Heat produced in a resistor.

realworld.title: Electric Iron
realworld.description: Uses high resistance coil (Nichrome) to convert large amount of electrical energy into heat.

notes.title: Electromagnetism
points: A current carrying conductor produces a magnetic field around it (Oersted).
Direction given by Right Hand Thumb Rule.

realworld.title: Electric Bell
realworld.description: Uses an electromagnet to repeatedly strike a gong.

notes.title: Principles
points: Change in magnetic flux linked with a coil induces an EMF (Faraday's Laws).
Direction of induced current opposes the cause (Lenz's Law).

realworld.title: Generator
realworld.description: AC Generator converts mechanical energy to electrical energy using EM induction.

notes.title: Components
points: Live (Phase), Neutral, and Earth wires.
Fuse: Safety device (series) with low melting point.
Switch: Connected in live wire.

realworld.title: Earthing
realworld.description: Earth wire connects metal case of appliances to ground to prevent electric shock.

notes.title: Difference
points: Heat: A form of energy which flows from a hotter body to a colder body. SI Unit: Joule (J).
Temperature: The degree of hotness or coldness of a body. Determine direction of heat flow. SI Unit: Kelvin (K).

formulas.title: Temperature Conversion
formulas.explanation: Relation between Kelvin and Celsius scales.

formulas.title: Fahrenheit Conversion
formulas.explanation: Relation between Celsius and Fahrenheit.

realworld.title: Thermometer
realworld.description: Mercury expands with rise in temperature, allowing us to measure body temperature.

notes.title: Comparison
points: Conduction: In solids, no actual movement of medium particles.
Convection: In fluids (liquids/gases), actual movement of medium particles.
Radiation: No medium required, electromagnetic waves.

notes.title: Mechanism
points: Heat transfer through molecular vibrations and free electron diffusion in solids.
Good Conductors: Metals (Copper, Silver).
Bad Conductors (Insulators): Wood, Glass, Plastic, Air.

realworld.title: Cooking Utensils
realworld.description: Pans are made of metal to conduct heat to food, while handles are made of plastic (insulator) to protect hands.

notes.title: Convection Current
points: Process where heated fluid becomes less dense and rises, while cooler, denser fluid moves down to take its place.
Responsible for Land Breeze and Sea Breeze.

realworld.title: Ventilation
realworld.description: Ventilators are placed high in rooms because warm, stale air rises and escapes, while fresh cool air enters from below.

notes.title: Principle
points: Heat Lost = Heat Gained (if no heat is lost to surroundings).
Based on the Law of Conservation of Energy.

notes.title: Properties
points: Heat transfer that requires no medium.
Travels at the speed of light.
Black surfaces are good absorbers and radiators of heat.

realworld.title: Solar Cooker
realworld.description: Solar cookers are painted black inside to maximize heat absorption from sunlight.

notes.title: Definition
points: The amount of heat energy required to raise the temperature of unit mass of a substance by 1°C (or 1 K).
SI Unit: J/kg K.
Water has a very high specific heat capacity (4200 J/kg K).

formulas.title: Heat Energy
formulas.explanation: m = mass, c = specific heat capacity, ΔT = Change in temperature.

realworld.title: Car Radiator Coolant
realworld.description: Water is used as a coolant because it can absorb a lot of heat without a large rise in temperature.

notes.title: Types
points: Latent Heat of Fusion: Solid to Liquid change at constant temperature (melting point).
Latent Heat of Vaporization: Liquid to Gas change at constant temperature (boiling point).

formulas.title: Change of State
formulas.explanation: L = Specific Latent Heat.

realworld.title: Steam Burns
realworld.description: Steam causes more severe burns than boiling water because it contains extra latent heat energy.

notes.title: Nucleus
points: Central positively charged electric core.
Contains Protons (p+) and Neutrons (n0).
Nucleons: Protons + Neutrons.

notes.title: Definition
points: Spontaneous emission of radiations (Alpha, Beta, Gamma) from the nucleus of an unstable atom.
It is a nuclear phenomenon.
Unaffected by physical or chemical changes.

realworld.title: Carbon Dating
realworld.description: Using C-14 isotope to determine the age of ancient fossils and artifacts.

notes.title: Comparison
points: Alpha (α): Helium nucleus (He2+). Positive charge. Low penetrating power, high ionizing power.
Beta (β): Fast moving electron (e-). Negative charge. Moderate penetrating power.
Gamma (γ): Electromagnetic wave. Neutral. High penetrating power, low ionizing power.

realworld.title: Cancer Treatment
realworld.description: Cobalt-60 emits gamma rays which are used to kill cancer cells (Radiotherapy).

topics.name: Uses and Hazards of Nuclear Energy

notes.title: Hazards
points: Biological damage: Genetic mutations, skin burns, cancer.
Safety: Lead shielding, thick concrete walls, dosimeters for workers.

notes.title: Nuclear Fission vs Fusion
points: Fission: Splitting of heavy nucleus (Uranium). Principle of Atom Bomb and Nuclear Reactiors.
Fusion: Combining light nuclei (Hydrogen). Principle of Hydrogen Bomb and Sun's energy.

formulas.title: Mass-Energy Equivalence
formulas.explanation: Einstein's equation relating mass defect to energy released.

realworld.title: Nuclear Power Plants
realworld.description: Controlled chain reaction of Uranium fission is used to generate electricity.

notes.title: Statement
points: The physical and chemical properties of elements are a periodic function of their atomic numbers (Moseley).

notes.title: Features
points: 7 Horizontal rows called Periods.
18 Vertical columns called Groups.
Elements in the same group have the same number of valence electrons and similar chemical properties.

realworld.title: Kitchen Organization
realworld.description: Just as spices are arranged by type in a kitchen for easy access, elements are arranged by properties in the periodic table.

notes.title: Special Groups
points: Group 1: Alkali Metals (Highly reactive).
Group 2: Alkaline Earth Metals.
Group 17: Halogens (Salt formers).
Group 18: Noble/Inert Gases (Stable octet).

realworld.title: Neon Lights
realworld.description: Noble gases like Neon and Argon are used in advertising signs and light bulbs due to their unreactive nature.

notes.title: Trends across Period (Left to Right)
points: Atomic Size: Decreases.
Ionization Potential: Increases.
Electron Affinity: Increases.
Electronegativity: Increases.
Metallic Character: Decreases.

notes.title: Trends down a Group (Top to Bottom)
points: Atomic Size: Increases.
Ionization Potential: Decreases.
Electron Affinity: Decreases.
Electronegativity: Decreases.
Metallic Character: Increases.

notes.title: Definition
points: Distance from the center of the nucleus to the outermost shell of electrons.

notes.title: Variation
points: Across Period: Increases from 1 to 4, then decreases to 0.
Down Group: Remains the same.

notes.title: Nature
points: Metals: Electron donors (Electropositive).
Non-metals: Electron acceptors (Electronegative).

realworld.title: Wires and Insulators
realworld.description: Copper (metal) is used for conducting electricity, while PVC (polymer/non-metal) is used as an insulator coating.

notes.title: Concept
points: Atoms tend to lose, gain, or share electrons to attain a stable electronic configuration of the nearest noble gas.
Octet: 8 electrons in valence shell.
Duplet: 2 electrons in valence shell (e.g., H, He, Li).

notes.title: Formation
points: Formed by complete transfer of electrons from a metal atom (electropositive) to a non-metal atom (electronegative).
Results in formation of Cations (+) and Anions (-).
Held together by strong electrostatic force of attraction (Electrovalent bond).

formulas.title: Sodium Chloride Formation
formulas.explanation: Formation of NaCl.

realworld.title: Table Salt
realworld.description: Common salt (NaCl) forms cubic crystals due to the regular arrangement of ions.

notes.title: Formation
points: Formed by mutual sharing of electron pairs between two non-metal atoms.
Single Bond: Sharing 1 pair (e.g., H-H).
Double Bond: Sharing 2 pairs (e.g., O=O).
Triple Bond: Sharing 3 pairs (e.g., N≡N).

realworld.title: Diamond
realworld.description: Hardest natural substance, formed by a strong network of covalent bonds between Carbon atoms.

notes.title: Non-polar
points: Shared pair is equally distributed between two identical atoms.
No charge separation. (e.g., H2, Cl2, O2).

notes.title: Polar
points: Shared pair is shifted towards the more electronegative atom.
Results in partial positive (δ+) and partial negative (δ-) charges.
Example: HCl, H2O.

realworld.title: Water as Solvent
realworld.description: Water dissolves many substances because its polar nature allows it to interact with ions and polar molecules.

notes.title: General Properties
points: Crystalline solids.
High melting and boiling points (Strong forces).
Soluble in water, insoluble in organic solvents.
Conduct electricity in molten or aqueous state (Ions are free to move).

notes.title: General Properties
points: Gases, liquids, or soft solids.
Low melting and boiling points (Weak Van der Waals forces).
Insoluble in water (except polar ones), soluble in organic solvents.
Non-conductors of electricity (No free ions).

topics.name: Definitions of Acids, Bases and Salts

notes.title: Arrhenius Theory
points: Acids: Substances that dissociate in water to give Hydrogen ions (H+) or Hydronium ions (H3O+). Example: HCl, H2SO4.
Bases: Substances that dissociate in water to give Hydroxyl ions (OH-). Example: NaOH, KOH.
Alkalis: Bases that are soluble in water.

realworld.title: Stomach Acid
realworld.description: Our stomach produces dilute HCl to help digest food and kill bacteria.

topics.name: Strong and Weak Acids and Bases

notes.title: Dissociation
points: Strong Acid/Base: Dissociates almost completely in aqueous solution, producing a high concentration of ions. (e.g., HCl, NaOH).
Weak Acid/Base: Dissociates only partially in aqueous solution, producing a low concentration of ions. (e.g., CH3COOH, NH4OH).

realworld.title: Vinegar
realworld.description: Vinegar contains Acetic Acid (CH3COOH), a weak acid used in cooking and preservation.

notes.title: Concept
points: A scale for measuring hydrogen ion concentration in a solution.
Range: 0 to 14.
pH < 7: Acidic.
pH = 7: Neutral.
pH > 7: Basic/Alkaline.

formulas.title: pH Definition
formulas.explanation: Negative logarithm of hydrogen ion concentration.

realworld.title: Tooth Decay
realworld.description: Tooth decay starts when the pH of the mouth is lower than 5.5, corroding the enamel.

notes.title: Color Changes
points: Litmus: Blue to Red (Acid), Red to Blue (Base).
Methyl Orange: Pink (Acid), Yellow (Base).
Phenolphthalein: Colorless (Acid), Pink (Base).

notes.title: Olfactory Indicators
points: Substances whose odor changes in acidic or basic media (e.g., Onion, Vanilla).

notes.title: Methods
points: Neutralization: Acid + Base -> Salt + Water.
Displacement: Active Metal + Acid -> Salt + Hydrogen.
Double Decomposition (Precipitation): Mixing two soluble salt solutions to get a precipitate.

formulas.title: Neutralization
formulas.explanation: Formation of Sodium Chloride.

realworld.title: Baking Soda
realworld.description: Used in baking powder to make cakes rise (releases CO2).

realworld.title: Plaster of Paris
realworld.description: Used by doctors for supporting fractured bones in the right position.

notes.title: Action of Alkalis
points: Sodium Hydroxide (NaOH) and Ammonium Hydroxide (NH4OH) are strong and weak alkalis respectively.
They are used to identify metal cations based on the color and solubility of the precipitate formed.

realworld.title: Water Treatment
realworld.description: Removal of heavy metals from industrial waste water often involves precipitation using alkalis.

notes.title: Using NaOH and NH4OH
points: Calcium (Ca2+): White pkt (insoluble in excess).
Copper (Cu2+): Blue ppt (insoluble in excess NaOH, soluble in excess NH4OH forming deep blue solution).
Iron (Fe2+): Dirty Green ppt.
Iron (Fe3+): Reddish Brown ppt.
Zinc (Zn2+): White gelatinous ppt (soluble in excess of both).
Lead (Pb2+): White chalky ppt (soluble in excess NaOH, insoluble in excess NH4OH).

notes.title: Colors
points: Sodium (Na+): Golden Yellow.
Potassium (K+): Lilac (Violet).
Calcium (Ca2+): Brick Red.

realworld.title: Fireworks
realworld.description: The vibrant colors in fireworks are produced by metal salts (e.g., Strontium for red, Barium for green).

notes.title: Definition
points: A double displacement reaction where two soluble salts react to form an insoluble solid (precipitate).

formulas.title: Example
formulas.explanation: Blue precipitate of Copper Hydroxide.

notes.title: Terms
points: Minerals: Naturally occurring compounds of metals.
Ores: Minerals from which metals can be extracted profitably.
Gangue/Matrix: Earthy impurities (sand, mud) present in the ore.

notes.title: Common Ores
points: Aluminium: Bauxite (Al2O3.2H2O).
Iron: Haematite (Fe2O3).
Zinc: Zinc Blende (ZnS).

realworld.title: Mining
realworld.description: Large scale mining operations extract ores like Bauxite to produce Aluminium for aircraft bodies.

notes.title: Methods
points: Gravity Separation (Hydraulic Washing): For heavy oxide ores (e.g., Haematite).
Froth Floatation: For light sulphide ores (e.g., Zinc Blende). Pine oil creates froth.
Magnetic Separation: For magnetic ores (e.g., Magnetite).

notes.title: Chemical Method (Bayer's Process)
points: Concentration of Bauxite using Sodium Hydroxide.

formulas.title: Bayer's Process
formulas.explanation: Conversion of Bauxite to Sodium Aluminate.

notes.title: Roasting vs Calcination
points: Roasting: Heating ore in PRESENCE of excess air (for Sulphide ores). ZnS + O2 -> ZnO + SO2.
Calcination: Heating ore in ABSENCE/LIMITED air (for Carbonate/Hydrated ores). ZnCO3 -> ZnO + CO2.

notes.title: Reduction
points: Reduction of Metal Oxide to Metal using Coke (Carbon), CO, or Electrolysis.

notes.title: Extraction of Aluminium (Hall-Heroult Process)
points: Electrolyte: Fused Alumina (Al2O3) + Cryolite (Na3AlF6) + Fluorspar (CaF2).
Cathode: Carbon lining (Al produced here).
Anode: Graphite rods (O2 produced here, burns as CO2).

formulas.title: Hall-Heroult Process Reactions
formulas.formula: Cathode: Al3+ + 3e- -> Al, Anode: O2- - 2e- -> [O]; C + 2[O] -> CO2
formulas.explanation: Reduction of Aluminium ions and oxidation of Oxygen ions.

notes.title: Electro-refining
points: Anode: Impure metal block.
Cathode: Thin strip of pure metal.
Electrolyte: Soluble salt of the metal.
Result: Pure metal deposits on Cathode; impurities settle as Anode Mud.

realworld.title: Copper Wiring
realworld.description: Electrical wires require 99.99% pure Copper, obtained via electrolytic refining.

notes.title: Definition
points: Homogeneous mixture of two or more metals, or a metal and a non-metal.

notes.title: Common Alloys
points: Brass (Cu + Zn): Utensils, cartridges.
Bronze (Cu + Sn): Statues, medals.
Stainless Steel (Fe + Ni + Cr): Cutlery, surgical instruments.
Duralumin (Al + Cu + Mg + Mn): Aircraft bodies (light and strong).

realworld.title: Stainless Steel
realworld.description: Kitchen cutlery is made of stainless steel to prevent rusting despite constant exposure to water.

notes.title: Characteristics of Carbon
points: Tetravalency: Carbon has a valency of 4.
Catenation: Typical property of carbon atoms to form bonds with other carbon atoms forming long chains/rings.
Isomerism: Compounds having same molecular formula but different structural formula.

notes.title: Features
points: Same general formula for all members.
Same functional group.
Successive members differ by -CH₂- group and 14u mass.
Similar chemical properties but gradation in physical properties.

notes.title: IUPAC Rules
points: Select longest carbon chain (Root word: Meth, Eth, Prop...).
Number the chain to give lowest number to substituents/functional groups.
Arrange prefixes alphabetically.

notes.title: Properties
points: Saturated hydrocarbons (Single bonds).
Undergo substitution reactions (e.g., Chlorination).

formulas.title: General Formula
formulas.explanation: n = 1 (Methane), n = 2 (Ethane)...

realworld.title: Natural Gas
realworld.description: Methane is the primary component of natural gas used for cooking.

notes.title: Properties
points: Unsaturated hydrocarbons (Double bond).
Undergo addition reactions (e.g., Hydrogenation).

formulas.title: General Formula
formulas.explanation: n = 2 (Ethene), n = 3 (Propene)...

realworld.title: Fruit Ripening
realworld.description: Ethene gas is used commercially to ripen fruits like bananas and mangoes.

notes.title: Properties
points: Unsaturated hydrocarbons (Triple bond).
Acidic nature of terminal alkynes.

formulas.title: General Formula
formulas.explanation: n = 2 (Ethyne)...

realworld.title: Welding
realworld.description: Ethyne (Acetylene) produces a very hot flame used for welding metals.

realworld.title: Ethanol
realworld.description: Used in medicines (tinctures), sanitizers, and as an additive to petrol.

realworld.title: Acetic Acid
realworld.description: Dilute acetic acid is used as vinegar for food preservation.

notes.title: Key Points
points: All living organisms are composed of cells.
The cell is the fundamental unit of structure and function in living things.
omnis cellula e cellula: All cells come from pre-existing cells (Virchow).

notes.title: Classification
points: Prokaryotic: No well-defined nucleus (e.g., Bacteria).
Eukaryotic: True nucleus with membrane-bound organelles (e.g., Plants, Animals).

notes.title: Differences
points: Plant Cell: Cell wall present, Large vacuole, Plastids (Chloroplasts) present.
Animal Cell: No cell wall, Small/no vacuoles, Centrosomes present.

notes.title: Structure
points: Lipid bilayer with embedded proteins (Fluid Mosaic Model).
Selectively permeable: Regulates entry and exit of substances.

notes.title: Function
points: Control center of the cell.
Contains genetic material (DNA in chromosomes).

notes.title: Powerhouse
points: Site of cellular respiration.
Generates energy in the form of ATP (Adenosine Triphosphate).

notes.title: Types
points: Rough ER (RER): With ribosomes, synthesizes proteins.
Smooth ER (SER): No ribosomes, synthesizes lipids.

notes.title: Function
points: Packaging and dispatching unit of the cell.
Formation of Lysosomes.

notes.title: Ribosomes
points: Site of protein synthesis.

notes.title: Lysosomes
points: Suicide bags of the cell.
Contain digestive enzymes to destroy worn-out organelles or foreign material.

notes.title: Mechanisms
points: Imbibition: Absorption of water by solid particles.
Diffusion: Movement from higher to lower concentration.
Osmosis: Movement of water across a semi-permeable membrane from dilute to concentrated solution.
Active Transport: Movement against concentration gradient using energy (ATP).

realworld.title: Raisins in Water
realworld.description: Raisins swell up when kept in water due to endosmosis.

notes.title: Process
points: Loss of water in the form of vapor from the aerial parts of the plant.
Occurs mainly through Stomata.
Significance: Cooling effect, creates Transpiration Pull (Ascent of Sap).

realworld.title: Cooling under Tree
realworld.description: It feels cooler under a tree during summer due to the cooling effect of transpiration.

notes.title: Phases
points: Light Reaction (Hill Reaction): Occurs in Grana. Photolysis of water, production of ATP and NADPH.
Dark Reaction (Calvin Cycle): Occurs in Stroma. Reduction of CO2 to Glucose using ATP and NADPH.

formulas.title: Chemical Equation
formulas.explanation: Overall reaction of photosynthesis.

notes.title: Types
points: Aerobic: Complete breakdown of glucose in presence of oxygen. End products: CO2, H2O, Energy (38 ATP).
Anaerobic: Incomplete breakdown in absence of oxygen. End products: Ethanol, CO2, Energy (2 ATP).

notes.title: Mechanism
points: Transport of food from leaves to other parts via Phloem.
Bidirectional flow.

notes.title: Nutrients
points: Macronutrients: Required in large quantities (N, P, K, Mg, Ca).
Micronutrients: Required in traces (Fe, Mn, Zn, Cu).

realworld.title: Fertilizers
realworld.description: NPK fertilizers are commonly used to supply Nitrogen, Phosphorus, and Potassium to crops.

notes.title: Enzymes
points: Saliva: Salivary Amylase (Starch -> Maltose).
Gastric Juice: Pepsin (Proteins -> Peptides), HCl (Activates Pepsin, kills germs).
Pancreatic Juice: Trypsin, Amylase, Lipase.
Intestinal Juice: Erepsin, Maltase, Lactase, sucrase.

realworld.title: Antacids
realworld.description: Magnesium hydroxide (Milk of Magnesia) neutralizes excess stomach acid.

notes.title: Mechanism
points: Inspiration: Diaphragm contracts (flattens), Ribs move out, thoracic volume increases, pressure decreases, air rushes in.
Expiration: Diaphragm relaxes (dome shape), Ribs move in, thoracic volume decreases, pressure increases, air rushes out.

notes.title: The Heart
points: Four chambers: 2 Auricles, 2 Ventricles.
Double Circulation: Pulmonary (Heart-Lungs-Heart) and Systemic (Heart-Body-Heart).
Systole (Contraction) and Diastole (Relaxation).

notes.title: Blood
points: RBCs (Transport O2), WBCs (Immunity), Platelets (Clotting).
Plasma: Liquid part.

realworld.title: Blood Pressure
realworld.description: Normal BP is 120/80 mmHg. High BP is Hypertension.

notes.title: Nephron
points: Structural and functional unit of kidney.
Ultrafiltration: Occurs in Glomerulus.
Selective Reabsorption: Useful substances (glucose, water) reabsorbed in PCT/Loop of Henle.
Tubular Secretion: Waste added to filtrate.

realworld.title: Dialysis
realworld.description: Used for patients with kidney failure to filter waste from blood.

notes.title: Divisions
points: CNS: Brain and Spinal Cord.
PNS: Cranial and Spinal nerves.
ANS: Sympathetic (Fight or Flight) and Parasympathetic (Rest and Digest).

notes.title: Reflex Action
points: Automatic, involuntary response to a stimulus.
Reflex Arc: Stimulus -> Receptor -> Sensory Neuron -> Spinal Cord -> Motor Neuron -> Effector -> Response.

realworld.title: Touching Hot Object
realworld.description: Withdrawing hand immediately upon touching a hot pan is a reflex action.

notes.title: Glands and Hormones
points: Pituitary: Growth Hormone (GH). Master Gland.
Thyroid: Thyroxine (Basal Metabolism). Deficiency causes Goitre.
Pancreas: Insulin (Lowers blood sugar), Glucagon (Raises blood sugar).
Adrenal: Adrenaline (Emergency hormone).

realworld.title: Iodized Salt
realworld.description: Iodine is essential for Thyroxine synthesis; iodized salt prevents Goitre.

notes.title: Definition of Health
points: WHO Definition: Health is a state of complete physical, mental, and social well-being and not merely the absence of disease or infirmity.

notes.title: Hygiene
points: Personal Hygiene: Cleanliness of body, oral hygiene, eye care, sleep, and physical exercise.
Social/Community Hygiene: Clean surroundings, proper disposal of waste, control of disease vectors (mosquitoes, flies), and clean drinking water.

realworld.title: Public Sanitation
realworld.description: Municipal garbage collection and sewage treatment plants are essential for maintaining community health to prevent outbreaks like cholera.

notes.title: Bacterial Diseases
points: Cholera: Caused by *Vibrio cholerae*. Symptoms: Severe diarrhea, dehydration. Spread by contaminated water.
Typhoid: Caused by *Salmonella typhi*. Symptoms: Constant fever, headache. Spread by contaminated food/water.
Tuberculosis (TB): Caused by *Mycobacterium tuberculosis*. affects lungs. BCG Vaccine prevents it.

notes.title: Viral Diseases
points: AIDS (Acquired Immuno Deficiency Syndrome): Caused by HIV. Attacks immune system.
COVID-19: Caused by SARS-CoV-2.
Dengue/Chikungunya: Spread by *Aedes* mosquito.

notes.title: Protozoan Diseases
points: Malaria: Caused by *Plasmodium*. Vector: Female *Anopheles* mosquito. Symptoms: Recurring fever with chills.

realworld.title: Mosquito Nets
realworld.description: Using pesticide-treated mosquito nets is a primary strategy to combat malaria in endemic regions.

notes.title: Examples
points: Diabetes Mellitus: Caused by insufficient insulin (pancreas). Symptoms: High blood sugar, excessive thirst.
Cardiovascular Diseases: Hypertension (High BP), Heart attack.
Cancer: Uncontrolled division of cells.
Allergies: Hypersensitivity of the immune system.

realworld.title: Insulin Injections
realworld.description: Type 1 Diabetics need daily insulin injections to manage blood sugar levels.

notes.title: Types of Immunity
points: Innate Immunity: Present from birth (Skin barriers, tears, stomach acid).
Acquired Immunity: Developed during lifetime.
Active Immunity: Body produces its own antibodies (after infection or vaccination).
Passive Immunity: Ready-made antibodies introduced (e.g., Mother's milk, Antivenom).

notes.title: Vaccination
points: Introducing weakened or killed germs to stimulate antibody production.
Vaccines: BCG (TB), DPT (Diphtheria, Pertussis, Tetanus), OPV (Polio), MMR (Measles, Mumps, Rubella).

notes.title: Antiseptics vs Disinfectants
points: Antiseptics: Mild chemical applied on body (e.g., Iodine, Spirit).
Disinfectants: Strong chemical applied on spots/floors (e.g., Phenol, Lysol).

realworld.title: Pulse Polio Programme
realworld.description: Mass immunization campaign in India to eradicate poliomyelitis by vaccinating all children under 5 years.

notes.title: Principles
points: Definition: Immediate help given to a victim before medical aid arrives.
ABC Rule: Airway, Breathing, Circulation.

notes.title: Common Scenarios
points: Burns: Pour cold water immediately.
Fracture: Do not move the limb; use a splint.
Bleeding: Apply pressure on the wound.
Snake Bite: Keep patient calm, keep bitten part below heart level, do not suck poison.

realworld.title: CPR
realworld.description: Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation is a technique used in emergencies like heart attack to manually preserve brain function.

notes.title: Definition
points: Small differences among individuals of the same species are called variations.
Causes: Genetic recombination (Meiosis), Mutation, Environment.

notes.title: Types
points: Somatic Variations: Acquired during lifetime, non-heritable.
Germinal Variations: Occur in germ cells, heritable (passed to offspring).

realworld.title: Height Differences
realworld.description: Height in humans is a range, not just tall or short, showing continuous variation.

realworld.title: Earlobe Attachment
realworld.description: Attached vs Free earlobes is a distinct trait with no intermediate forms.

notes.title: Concept
points: The transmission of genetically based characteristics from parents to offspring.
Genetics: The study of heredity and variation.

notes.title: Terminologies
points: Gene: Functional unit of heredity.
Allele: Alternative forms of a gene (e.g., T and t).
Genotype: Genetic makeup (e.g., TT, Tt, tt).
Phenotype: Physical observable characteristic (e.g., Tall, Dwarf).
Homozygous: Identical alleles (TT or tt).
Heterozygous: Different alleles (Tt).

realworld.title: Eye Color
realworld.description: Children often inherit eye color from their parents, though it follows complex patterns.

notes.title: Monohybrid Cross
points: A cross considering only one pair of contrasting characters.
Law of Dominance: In a heterozygous individual, the dominant allele expresses itself.
Law of Segregation: During gamete formation, the two alleles separate so that each gamete receives only one.

notes.title: Dihybrid Cross
points: A cross considering two pairs of contrasting characters.
Law of Independent Assortment: Alleles of different genes segregate independently of one another during gamete formation.

formulas.title: Monohybrid Ratio
formulas.explanation: Result of F2 generation.

formulas.title: Dihybrid Ratio
formulas.explanation: Result of F2 generation (e.g., Round Yellow : Round Green : Wrinkled Yellow : Wrinkled Green).

notes.title: Sex Determination
points: Humans have 23 pairs of chromosomes (22 autosomes + 1 pair sex chromosomes).
Male: XY, Female: XX.
The sex of the child is determined by the sperm (carrying X or Y).

notes.title: Sex-Linked Inheritance
points: Genes located on X-chromosome are X-linked.
Examples: Color Blindness, Haemophilia (more common in males as they have only one X chromosome).

realworld.title: Color Blindness Testing
realworld.description: Ishihara plates are used to test for red-green color blindness, a genetic condition.

notes.title: Darwin's Theory
points: Overproduction: Organisms produce more offspring than can survive.
Struggle for Existence: Competition for food, space, mate.
Variation: Useful variations help in survival.
Survival of the Fittest: Nature selects the best adapted.
Origin of New Species: Accumulation of favorable variations over generations.

notes.title: Human Evolution
points: Australopithecus -> Homo habilis -> Homo erectus -> Neanderthal -> Cro-Magnon -> Homo sapiens (Modern Man).

realworld.title: Peppered Moth
realworld.description: Light moths were camouflaged on lichen-covered trees. During industrial revolution, trees turned black, and dark moths survived better (Natural Selection).

notes.title: Components
points: Biotic Components: All living organisms (Plants, Animals, Microorganisms).
Abiotic Components: Non-living factors (Temperature, Light, Soil, Water).
Interaction: Biotic and Abiotic components interact to form a stable ecosystem.

realworld.title: Pond Ecosystem
realworld.description: A garden pond with fish, frogs (biotic) and water, rocks, sunlight (abiotic) functioning as a self-sustaining unit.

notes.title: Trophic Levels
points: Producers (Autotrophs): Green plants that make their own food.
Consumers (Heterotrophs): Primary (Herbivores), Secondary (Carnivores), Tertiary (Top Carnivores).
Decomposers: Break down dead organic matter.

notes.title: Energy Flow
points: Unidirectional flow of energy from Sun -> Producers -> Consumers.
10% Law: Only 10% of energy is transferred to the next trophic level.

realworld.title: Forest Food Web
realworld.description: Grass -> Deer -> Tiger. If deer population decreases, tigers starve and grass overgrows, disrupting balance.

notes.title: Classification
points: Renewable Resources: Replenished naturally (Solar energy, Wind, Water).
Non-Renewable Resources: Finite stock (Coal, Petroleum, Minerals).

realworld.title: Solar Panels
realworld.description: Homes using solar panels to generate electricity reduce dependence on fossil fuels.

notes.title: Types
points: Air Pollution: Burning fossil fuels, industrial emissions (SO2, NO2). Causes Acid Rain, Global Warming.
Water Pollution: Sewage, Industrial effluents. Causes Eutrophication, waterborne diseases.
Soil Pollution: Pesticides, Plastic waste.
Noise Pollution: Traffic, Loudspeakers.

realworld.title: Delhi Smog
realworld.description: Severe smog in Delhi during winters due to vehicle emissions and stubble burning affects respiratory health.

notes.title: Waste Management
points: Segregation: Biodegradable (Wet waste) vs Non-biodegradable (Dry waste).
3Rs: Reduce, Reuse, Recycle.
Composting: Turning organic waste into manure.

notes.title: Swachh Bharat Abhiyan
points: Clean India Mission to ensure hygiene, waste management and sanitation.

realworld.title: Ban on Single-use Plastic
realworld.description: Many cities have banned plastic bags and straws to reduce non-biodegradable waste.

notes.title: Basics
points: GST is a destination-based consumption tax.
Intra-state transaction: Within the same state (CGST + SGST apply).
Inter-state transaction: From one state to another (IGST applies).
Input GST: Tax paid on purchase (Input Credit).
Output GST: Tax collected on sale.
Net GST Payable = Output GST - Input GST.

formulas.title: Intra-state Tax Calculation
formulas.explanation: If rate is 18%, CGST = 9%, SGST = 9%.

formulas.title: Inter-state Tax Calculation
formulas.explanation: Full rate goes to Central Govt.

realworld.title: Restaurant Bill
realworld.description: Seeing CGST and SGST on a food bill illustrates how taxes are split between Center and State.

notes.title: Recurring Deposit Account
points: Account holder deposits a specific amount every month for a fixed period.
At maturity, the depositor gets the principal deposited plus interest.
Principal (P) = Monthly Installment.
n = Number of months.

formulas.title: Interest
formulas.explanation: P=Monthly Deposit, n=Months, r=Rate of Interest (p.a).

formulas.title: Maturity Value
formulas.explanation: Total amount received at the end of the term.

realworld.title: Savings Goal
realworld.description: Planning to buy a bike by saving a fixed amount monthly in an RD account to earn interest.

notes.title: Terminology
points: Nominal Value (NV) / Face Value (FV): Original value of a share printed on the share certificate.
Market Value (MV): Price at which share is traded in the market (At par, At premium/above par, At discount/below par).
Dividend: Profit distributed to shareholders, always calculated on Face Value.
Rate of Dividend: Percentage of FV given as profit.

formulas.title: Dividend
formulas.formula: Annual Dividend = (Dividend% / 100) * FV * No. of Shares
formulas.explanation: Dividend is independent of Market Value.

formulas.title: Return on Investment (ROI)
formulas.explanation: Use to compare profitability.

formulas.title: Investment Relation
formulas.formula: No. of Shares * MV = Invested Amount
formulas.explanation: Cost to buy shares.

realworld.title: Stock Market
realworld.description: Buying shares of companies like Reliance or Tata Motors to benefit from their growth and dividends.

notes.title: Rules
points: Adding/Subtracting same number to both sides doesn't change inequality sign.
Multiplying/Dividing by positive number doesn't change inequality sign.
Multiplying/Dividing by NEGATIVE number REVERSES the inequality sign.
Solution Set: The set of values which satisfy the inequation.

notes.title: Number Line Representation
points: Hollow circle: For < or > (value not included).
Solid circle: For ≤ or ≥ (value included).

realworld.title: Budgeting
realworld.description: Spending ≤ Earnings. This constraint is a linear inequation essential for financial health.

realworld.title: Safety Limits
realworld.description: Elevator capacity ≤ 1000kg. Exceeding this poses a risk.

notes.title: Definitions
points: A polynomial is an algebraic expression consisting of variables and coefficients, that involves only the operations of addition, subtraction, multiplication, and non-negative integer exponents of variables.
Degree of a polynomial: The highest power of the variable in the polynomial.

notes.title: Remainder Theorem
points: If a polynomial f(x) is divided by (x - a), the remainder is f(a).
If divided by (ax + b), remainder is f(-b/a).

notes.title: Factor Theorem
points: If f(a) = 0, then (x - a) is a factor of the polynomial f(x).
Conversely, if (x - a) is a factor of f(x), then f(a) = 0.

realworld.title: Cryptography
realworld.description: Polynomial factorization is a key concept used in error correcting codes and some cryptographic algorithms.

notes.title: Standard Form
points: An equation of the form ax² + bx + c = 0, where a, b, c are real numbers and a ≠ 0.

notes.title: Nature of Roots
points: Discriminant (D) = b² - 4ac.
If D > 0: Two distinct real roots.
If D = 0: Two equal real roots.
If D < 0: No real roots (Imaginary).

formulas.title: Discriminant
formulas.explanation: Determines the nature of the roots.

realworld.title: Projectile Motion
realworld.description: The path of a projectile (like a thrown ball) is parabolic and can be modeled by a quadratic equation.

notes.title: Methods
points: Factorisation Method: Splitting the middle term.
Quadratic Formula (Sridharacharya's Rule).

formulas.title: Quadratic Formula
formulas.explanation: Used to find the roots of any quadratic equation ax² + bx + c = 0.

formulas.title: Sum and Product of Roots
formulas.explanation: Relationship between roots and coefficients.

notes.title: Definition
points: A sequence of numbers in which the difference between any two consecutive terms is constant.
Common Difference (d) = a₂ - a₁.

formulas.title: General Term (nth term)
formulas.explanation: a = first term, n = number of terms, d = common difference.

formulas.title: Sum of n terms
formulas.formula: Sn = n/2 [2a + (n-1)d] OR Sn = n/2 (a + l)
formulas.explanation: l is the last term (an).

realworld.title: Savings Schemes
realworld.description: Calculating total savings over time where a fixed amount is added periodically (Simple Interest) follows an AP.

realworld.title: Seating Arrangement
realworld.description: Stadium seats often increase by a fixed number in each successive row.

notes.title: Basics
points: Order of a matrix: m x n (m rows, n columns).
Types: Row matrix, Column matrix, Square matrix (m=n), Zero/Null matrix, Identity/Unit matrix (I).

notes.title: Operations
points: Addition/Subtraction: Possible only if orders are same. Add/Subtract corresponding elements.
Multiplication: Matrix A (m x n) and B (n x p) -> Product AB is of order m x p.

formulas.title: Multiplication Rule
formulas.explanation: Element c_ij is sum of products of elements of ith row of A and jth column of B.

realworld.title: Computer Graphics
realworld.description: Matrices are used to represent and manipulate 3D models, rotation, scaling, and translation in video games.

notes.title: Reflection
points: Reflection in x-axis: P(x, y) -> P'(x, -y).
Reflection in y-axis: P(x, y) -> P'(-x, y).
Reflection in origin: P(x, y) -> P'(-x, -y).
Invariant Point: A point which remains unchanged after reflection (lies on the line of reflection).

notes.title: Section Formula
points: Internal Division: Point P(x, y) divides segment AB in ratio m:n.
Mid-point Formula: Special case where m:n = 1:1.

formulas.title: Distance Formula
formulas.explanation: Distance between two points.

formulas.title: Section Formula
formulas.explanation: Coordinates of point dividing line segment internally in ratio m:n.

formulas.title: Mid-point Formula
formulas.explanation: Coordinates of the midpoint of a line segment.

formulas.title: Equation of a Line
formulas.explanation: m = slope (tan θ), c = y-intercept.

formulas.title: Slope Formula
formulas.explanation: Slope of a line passing through two points.

formulas.title: Point-Slope form
formulas.explanation: Equation of line with slope m passing through (x₁, y₁).

realworld.title: GPS
realworld.description: Global Positioning System uses coordinates to pinpoint locations on the Earth's surface.

notes.title: Tests for Similarity
points: Two triangles are similar if their corresponding angles are equal (Equiangular).
AA / AAA Similarity: If two angles of one triangle are equal to two angles of another triangle, then the two triangles are similar.
SAS Similarity: If one angle of a triangle is equal to one angle of another triangle and the sides including these angles are proportional.
SSS Similarity: If the three sides of one triangle are proportional to the three corresponding sides of another triangle.

notes.title: Basic Proportionality Theorem (BPT/Thales Theorem)
points: If a line is drawn parallel to one side of a triangle to intersect the other two sides in distinct points, the other two sides are divided in the same ratio.

formulas.title: Areas of Similar Triangles
formulas.explanation: The ratio of the areas of two similar triangles is equal to the square of the ratio of their corresponding sides.

realworld.title: Map Scales
realworld.description: Maps use similarity principles to represent large areas on small paper, maintaining correct proportions.

realworld.title: Photography
realworld.description: Enlarging or reducing a photo maintains the same shape but changes size, a perfect example of similarity.

notes.title: Angle Properties
points: The angle subtended by an arc at the center is double the angle subtended by it at any point on the remaining part of the circle.
Angles in the same segment of a circle are equal.
Angle in a semi-circle is a right angle (90°).

notes.title: Cyclic Properties
points: Cyclic Quadrilateral: A quadrilateral whose vertices lie on a circle.
The opposite angles of a cyclic quadrilateral are supplementary (sum is 180°).
The exterior angle of a cyclic quadrilateral is equal to the interior opposite angle.

notes.title: Tangent and Radius
points: The tangent at any point of a circle is perpendicular to the radius through the point of contact.

notes.title: Tangents from Exterior Point
points: Two tangents can be drawn from an external point to a circle.
The lengths of two tangents drawn from an external point to a circle are equal.
They subtend equal angles at the center.

notes.title: Touching Circles
points: If two circles touch each other, the point of contact lies on the straight line joining their centers.

realworld.title: Gears and Pulleys
realworld.description: Belts connecting two pulleys act as common tangents to the two circles (pulleys).

notes.title: Properties
points: A straight line drawn from the center of a circle to bisect a chord (which is not a diameter) is perpendicular to the chord.
Conversely, the perpendicular from the center of a circle to a chord bisects the chord.
Equal chords are equidistant from the center.
Chords equidistant from the center are equal in length.

notes.title: Alternate Segment Theorem
points: If a line touches a circle and from the point of contact a chord is drawn, the angles which this chord makes with the given line are equal respectively to the angles formed in the corresponding alternate segments.

notes.title: Intersecting Chords
points: If two chords intersects internally or externally, then the product of the lengths of their segments is equal (PA × PB = PC × PD).

formulas.title: Tangent-Secant Theorem
formulas.explanation: If PAB is a secant to a circle intersecting the circle at A and B, and PT is a tangent segment, then PA × PB = PT².

realworld.title: Arch Bridges
realworld.description: The design of arch bridges relies on the properties of circular arcs to distribute weight evenly.

notes.title: Definition
points: The ratios of the sides of a right-angled triangle with respect to its acute angles are called trigonometric ratios.
In a right triangle with angle θ: Perpendicular (Opposite), Base (Adjacent), Hypotenuse.

formulas.title: Basic Ratios
formulas.formula: sin θ = P/H, cos θ = B/H, tan θ = P/B
formulas.explanation: P=Perpendicular, B=Base, H=Hypotenuse (SOH CAH TOA).

formulas.title: Reciprocal Ratios
formulas.formula: cosec θ = 1/sin θ, sec θ = 1/cos θ, cot θ = 1/tan θ
formulas.explanation: Reciprocal relationships.

formulas.title: Quotient Ratios
formulas.formula: tan θ = sin θ / cos θ, cot θ = cos θ / sin θ
formulas.explanation: Relationship between tan, cot with sin and cos.

notes.title: Concept
points: An equation involving trigonometric ratios of an angle is called a trigonometric identity if it is true for all values of the angle.

formulas.title: Square Identities
formulas.explanation: Fundamental identity derived from Pythagoras theorem.

formulas.title: Sec-Tan Identity
formulas.explanation: Valid for 0° ≤ θ < 90°.

formulas.title: Cosec-Cot Identity
formulas.explanation: Valid for 0° < θ ≤ 90°.

notes.title: Application
points: Trigonometry is used to find heights of objects (towers, mountains) and distances between points without directly measuring them.
Line of Sight: The line drawn from the eye of an observer to the point in the object viewed by the observer.

realworld.title: Navigation
realworld.description: Used in GPS and satellite systems to calculate positions and distances on Earth.

realworld.title: Architecture
realworld.description: Architects use trigonometry to calculate roof slopes, light angles, and structural loads.

notes.title: Angle of Elevation
points: The angle formed by the line of sight with the horizontal when the point being viewed is above the horizontal level.
Observer looks upwards.

notes.title: Angle of Depression
points: The angle formed by the line of sight with the horizontal when the point being viewed is below the horizontal level.
Observer looks downwards.
Numerically, Angle of Elevation = Angle of Depression (Alternate Interior Angles).

realworld.title: Aviation
realworld.description: Pilots use angles of depression to calculate the correct descent path for landing on a runway.

notes.title: Methods to find Mean
points: Direct Method: Used when frequencies and values are small.
Short-cut (Assumed Mean) Method: Used to simplify calculations when values are large.
Step-deviation Method: Used when class sizes are equal and values are large, to further simplify calculations.

formulas.title: Direct Method
formulas.explanation: Where f is frequency and x is the variate (or mid-value of class).

formulas.title: Short-cut Method
formulas.explanation: Where A is Assumed Mean, and d = x - A (deviation).

formulas.title: Step-deviation Method
formulas.explanation: Where u = (x - A) / h, and h is the class size (width).

realworld.title: Average Score
realworld.description: Calculating the average marks of a class to understand the general performance level.

notes.title: Definition
points: The middlemost value of a distribution which divides it into two equal parts.
It is a positional average.

notes.title: Finding Median
points: For individual discrete series: Arrange in ascending order. If n is odd, Median = ((n+1)/2)th term. If n is even, Median = Average of (n/2)th and ((n/2)+1)th terms.
For grouped data: Can be found graphically using Ogive or by formula.

formulas.title: Median Formula (Grouped Data)
formulas.explanation: L=Lower limit of median class, n=Total frequency, cf=Cumulative frequency of preceding class, f=Frequency of median class, h=Class size.

realworld.title: Real Estate Prices
realworld.description: Median price is often used instead of mean for house prices because it is not skewed by extremely expensive mansions.

notes.title: Definition
points: The value which occurs most frequently in a data set.
A distribution can be unimodal, bimodal, or multimodal.

notes.title: Finding Mode
points: For ungrouped data: The observation with the maximum frequency.
For grouped data: Found graphically using a Histogram or by formula.

formulas.title: Mode Formula (Grouped Data)
formulas.explanation: L=Lower limit of modal class, f1=Frequency of modal class, f0=Frequency of class preceding modal class, f2=Frequency of class succeeding it, h=Class size.

formulas.title: Empirical Relationship
formulas.explanation: Relationship between Mean, Median and Mode for a moderately skewed distribution.

realworld.title: Retail
realworld.description: Shopkeepers stock shoe sizes based on the mode (most popular size) to maximize sales.

notes.title: Ogive
points: A curve obtained by plotting cumulative frequencies against the upper limits (Less than Ogive) or lower limits (More than Ogive) of class intervals.
Less than Ogive: Plot points (Upper Limit, Corresponding Cumulative Frequency).
Intersection: The point where 'Less than' and 'More than' Ogives intersect gives the Median on the x-axis.

notes.title: Finding Quartiles
points: Median (Q2): Value at N/2 on y-axis projected to curve and then to x-axis.
Lower Quartile (Q1): Value at N/4 on y-axis projected to x-axis.
Upper Quartile (Q3): Value at 3N/4 on y-axis projected to x-axis.
Inter Quartile Range: Q3 - Q1.

notes.title: Basic Concepts
points: Random Experiment: An experiment in which all possible outcomes are known and the exact outcome cannot be predicted in advance.
Sample Space (S): The set of all possible outcomes of a random experiment.
Event (E): Any subset of a sample space.
Elementary Event: An event having only one outcome.
Sure Event: An event that is certain to happen (Probability = 1).
Impossible Event: An event that cannot happen (Probability = 0).

notes.title: Definition
points: The theoretical probability of an event E is defined as the ratio of the number of outcomes favorable to the event to the total number of all possible outcomes of the experiment.

formulas.title: Probability Formula
formulas.explanation: Where n(E) is the number of favorable outcomes and n(S) is the total number of possible outcomes.

formulas.title: Range of Probability
formulas.explanation: Probability of an event always lies between 0 and 1 (inclusive).

formulas.title: Complementary Event
formulas.explanation: The sum of the probability of an event happening and not happening is 1.

realworld.title: Weather Forecasting
realworld.description: Meteorologists use probability to predict the percentage chance of rain or snow for a specific day.

notes.title: Coins
points: One Coin: S = {H, T}, Total = 2.
Two Coins: S = {HH, HT, TH, TT}, Total = 4.
Three Coins: S = {HHH, HHT, HTH, THH, HTT, THT, TTH, TTT}, Total = 8.

notes.title: Dice
points: Two Dice: Total outcomes = 36 (e.g., (1,1), (1,2)...(6,6)).

notes.title: Playing Cards
points: Total cards: 52.
Suits: 4 (Spades, Clubs, Hearts, Diamonds), each has 13 cards.
Colors: 26 Red (Hearts, Diamonds), 26 Black (Spades, Clubs).
Face Cards: 12 (4 Kings, 4 Queens, 4 Jacks).

realworld.title: Insurance
realworld.description: Insurance companies use probability statistics to determine premiums based on the likelihood of a claim.

realworld.title: Sports Strategies
realworld.description: Coaches and analysts use probability to decide plays, such as whether to go for a 2-point conversion in football.

notes.title: Causes
points: Political: Doctrine of Lapse (Dalhousie), Annexation of Awadh.
Social & Religious: Interference in customs (Sati abolition, Widow Remarriage Act), Fear of mass conversion.
Economic: Ruin of trade and handicrafts, Heavy taxation, Drain of Wealth.
Military: Lower salaries for Indian soldiers, General Service Enlistment Act, Introduction of Enfield Rifles (Greased Cartridges).

notes.title: Consequences
points: End of East India Company's rule; Power transferred to the British Crown (Govt of India Act 1858).
Queen's Proclamation: Promise of religious non-interference, equal treatment.
Reorganization of the Army (Divide and Rule policy).

realworld.title: Mangal Pandey
realworld.description: Mangal Pandey's revolt at Barrackpore is often cited as the immediate spark that ignited the uprising.

realworld.title: Rani Lakshmibai
realworld.description: Queen of Jhansi who became a symbol of resistance against British rule, famous for dying in battle.

notes.title: Factors Promoting Nationalism
points: Economic Exploitation: Famines, poverty, and destruction of industries.
Repressive Policies: Vernacular Press Act (1878), Arms Act (1878) by Lord Lytton.
Socio-Religious Reforms: Efforts by Raja Rammohan Roy, Swami Vivekananda to unite society.
Western Education: Spread of democratic ideas (Liberty, Equality).
Role of Press: Newspapers like 'The Hindu', 'Amrita Bazar Patrika' criticized British policies.

topics.name: Formation of the Indian National Congress

notes.title: Foundation
points: Founded: December 1885 by A.O. Hume (retired civil servant).
First Session: Bombay, presided by W.C. Bonnerjee, attended by 72 delegates.

notes.title: Phases
points: Early Nationalists (Moderates) (1885-1905): Believed in constitutional methods (3Ps - Petition, Prayer, Protest). Leaders: Dadabhai Naoroji, G.K. Gokhale.
Assertive Nationalists (Extremists) (1905-1919): Demanded Swaraj, believed in mass action. Leaders: Bal Gangadhar Tilak, Bipin Chandra Pal, Lala Lajpat Rai (Lal-Bal-Pal).

realworld.title: INC Today
realworld.description: The Indian National Congress remains a major political party in India, tracing its roots back to this movement.

notes.title: The Event (1905)
points: Proposed by Lord Curzon.
Official Reason: Administrative convenience to govern a large province.
Real Motive: To curb the rising tide of nationalism in Bengal and divide Hindus and Muslims.

notes.title: Anti-Partition Movement
points: Swadeshi Movement: Use of Indian goods, promotion of indigenous industries.
Boycott Movement: Boycott of British goods, schools, and courts.

notes.title: Ideology
points: Satyagraha: Truth-force, non-violent resistance.
Ahimsa: Non-violence.

notes.title: Major Movements
points: Non-Cooperation Movement (1920-1922): Triggered by Rowlatt Act, Jallianwala Bagh massacre, Khilafat issue. Suspended after Chauri Chaura incident.
Civil Disobedience Movement (1930): Started with the Dandi March (Salt Satyagraha). Breaking of Salt Laws.
Gandhi-Irwin Pact (1931): Suspension of movement for Round Table Conference.

realworld.title: Sabarmati Ashram
realworld.description: Gandhi's base for his activism, serving as a school for non-violence and self-reliance.

notes.title: Overview
points: Launched: August 1942.
Resolution: Passed at Bombay session of AICC.
Slogan: 'Do or Die' given by Mahatma Gandhi.
Causes: Failure of Cripps Mission (no guarantee of immediate independence), Threat of Japanese invasion during WWII.

notes.title: Significance
points: Mass uprising without leadership (leaders arrested early).
Establishment of parallel governments in some areas.
Demonstrated that British could no longer rule India against its will.

notes.title: Mountbatten Plan
points: June 3 Plan: Proposed partition of India into two dominions - India and Pakistan.
Accepted by both Congress and Muslim League.

notes.title: Indian Independence Act 1947
points: Ended British rule on August 15, 1947.
Abolished the office of Viceroy.
Constituent Assemblies of both dominions empowered to frame constitutions.
Princely states given choice to join either dominion.

realworld.title: Wagah Border
realworld.description: The daily retreat ceremony at the Wagah border symbolizes the rivalry and shared history resulting from the Partition.

notes.title: Causes
points: Aggressive Nationalism and Imperialism.
System of Alliances: Triple Alliance (Germany, Austria-Hungary, Italy) vs Triple Entente (Britain, France, Russia).
Sarajevo Crisis (Immediate Cause): Assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand (June 28, 1914).

notes.title: Results
points: Treaty of Versailles (1919): Imposed harsh terms on Germany (War guilt clause, heavy reparations, territorial loss).
Territorial Changes: Disintegration of Ottoman, Austro-Hungarian empires.
Formation of League of Nations.

realworld.title: Trench Warfare
realworld.description: WWI is famous for trench warfare on the Western Front, leading to a stalemate and massive casualties.

notes.title: Fascism (Italy)
points: Leader: Benito Mussolini.
Ideology: Ultra-nationalism, anti-communist, one-party rule, suppression of dissent.
Aims: Restore the glory of the Roman Empire.

notes.title: Nazism (Germany)
points: Leader: Adolf Hitler.
Ideology: Racial supremacy (Aryans), Anti-Semitism, abrogation of Treaty of Versailles.
Means: Gestapo (Secret police), Propaganda, Concentration camps.

notes.title: Causes
points: Weimar Republic's failure and Rise of Hitler.
Failure of League of Nations to check aggression (Manchuria, Abyssinia).
Invasion of Poland: Germany attacked Poland on Sept 1, 1939 (Immediate Cause).
Japanese Policy of Expansion.

notes.title: Consequences
points: Defeat of Axis Powers (Germany, Italy, Japan).
Formation of United Nations (1945).
Beginning of Cold War (USA vs USSR).

realworld.title: Hiroshima Peace Memorial
realworld.description: Preserves the Genbaku Dome as a reminder of the atomic bombing on August 6, 1945.

notes.title: Objectives
points: Maintain international peace and security.
Develop friendly relations among nations.
Achieve international cooperation in solving problems.

notes.title: Principal Organs
points: General Assembly: Deliberative body, all members have one vote.
Security Council: Enforcement body, 5 permanent members (veto power) and 10 non-permanent.
International Court of Justice (ICJ): Hague, Netherlands. Settles legal disputes.
Secretariat: Administrative wing headed by Secretary-General.
Economic and Social Council (ECOSOC).

realworld.title: UN Peacekeeping
realworld.description: Blue Helmets deployed to conflict zones to protect civilians and maintain peace.

topics.name: Meaning and Need for a Constitution

notes.title: Definition
points: A comprehensive document containing the set of rules according to which the government of a country runs.
It regulates the position and powers of the three organs of the government: Legislature, Executive, and Judiciary.

notes.title: Need
points: Defines the nature of the country's political system.
Protects citizens from arbitrary exercise of power.
Ensures minority rights are protected.
Established the Rule of Law.

topics.name: Salient Features of the Indian Constitution

notes.title: Key Features
points: Single Citizenship: Unlike USA, Indians have only one citizenship.
Universal Adult Franchise: Right to vote for all citizens above 18 years (61st Amendment reduced it from 21 to 18).
Fundamental Rights and Duties: Guarantees rights and prescribes duties.
Welfare State: Through Directive Principles.
Lengthiest Written Constitution: Originally 395 Articles, now more than 448.

notes.title: Rigidity and Flexibility
points: Rigid: Some provisions require special majority + ratification by states (e.g., Election of President).
Flexible: Some provisions can be amended by simple majority (e.g., Changing state boundaries).

realworld.title: Voter ID Card
realworld.description: The Elector's Photo Identity Card (EPIC) allows every adult citizen to participate in democracy.

notes.title: Nature
points: Enshrined in Part III (Articles 12-35).
Justiciable: Enforceable by courts (Writs can be issued).
Not absolute: Reasonable restrictions apply.

notes.title: The Six Rights
points: Right to Equality (Art 14-18).
Right to Freedom (Art 19-22): Speech, Assembly, Association, Movement, Residence, Profession.
Right against Exploitation (Art 23-24): Ban on forced labor and child labor.
Right to Freedom of Religion (Art 25-28).
Cultural and Educational Rights (Art 29-30).
Right to Constitutional Remedies (Art 32): Heart and Soul of Constitution.

realworld.title: RTI Act
realworld.description: Right to Information Act (2005) empowers citizens to question the government, derived from freedom of speech.

notes.title: Overview
points: Part IV (Articles 36-51).
Non-Justiciable: Cannot be enforced by courts.
Aim: To establish a Welfare State and insure social and economic democracy.

notes.title: Classifications
points: Socialistic Principles: Equal pay, decent standard of living.
Gandhian Principles: Village Panchayats, prohibition of intoxicating drinks.
Liberal-Intellectual Principles: Uniform Civil Code, separation of judiciary from executive.

realworld.title: MGNREGA
realworld.description: Aimed at guaranteeing the 'right to work', implementing the directive principle of securing livelihood.

notes.title: Details
points: Part IV-A (Article 51A).
Added by 42nd Amendment (1976) on Swaran Singh Committee recommendation.
Total 11 duties (11th added by 86th Amendment - education for children 6-14).

notes.title: Key Duties
points: Respect the Constitution, Flag, and Anthem.
Cherish and follow noble ideals of freedom struggle.
Uphold sovereignty, unity, and integrity of India.
Protect natural environment.
Scietific temper and spirit of inquiry.

realworld.title: Cinema Halls Anthem
realworld.description: Standing up for the National Anthem in various public spheres is a practice of this fundamental duty.

notes.title: The President
points: Head of State and Supreme Commander of Defence Forces.
Qualifications: Citizen of India, 35 years of age, qualified for election to Lok Sabha.
Election: By an Electoral College (Elected members of Parliament and State Assemblies).
Powers: Executive appointments, Legislative (summoning sessions), Financial (Budget), Judicial (Pardoning), Emergency powers.

notes.title: The Vice-President
points: Ex-officio Chairman of Rajya Sabha.
Qualifications: Citizen of India, 35 years of age, qualified for election to Rajya Sabha.
Function: Acts as President in their absence.

realworld.title: Rashtrapati Bhavan
realworld.description: The official residence of the President of India, located in New Delhi, symbolizing the highest office in the land.

topics.name: The Prime Minister and Council of Ministers

notes.title: The Prime Minister
points: Head of Government and leader of the majority party in Lok Sabha.
Appointment: By the President.
Functions: Advises President on appointment of ministers, coordinates government policy, link between President and Cabinet.

notes.title: Council of Ministers
points: Composition: Cabinet Ministers, Ministers of State, Deputy Ministers.
Collective Responsibility: The entire ministry resigns if a Vote of No Confidence is passed in the Lok Sabha.

notes.title: Lok Sabha (Lower House)
points: Composition: Max 550 members elected by Universal Adult Franchise.
Term: 5 years (can be dissolved earlier).
Speaker: Presides over sessions, maintains order, certifies Money Bills.

notes.title: Rajya Sabha (Upper House)
points: Composition: Max 250 members (12 nominated by President).
Nature: Permanent body, not subject to dissolution. 1/3rd members retire every 2 years.
Election: By elected members of State Legislative Assemblies (Single Transferable Vote).

realworld.title: New Parliament Building
realworld.description: Part of the Central Vista Redevelopment Project, representing a modern India.

notes.title: Overview
points: Apex court of India, guardian of the Constitution.
Composition: Chief Justice of India (CJI) and other judges (max 34).
Appointment: By President in consultation with judges (Collegium System).

notes.title: Jurisdiction
points: Original: Disputes between Centre and States or between States.
Appellate: Appeals against High Court judgments.
Advisory: President seeks opinion on law/fact.
Writ Jurisdiction: Enforcement of Fundamental Rights (Article 32).

realworld.title: Basic Structure Doctrine
realworld.description: Kesavananda Bharati case (1973) ruling that Parliament cannot alter the basic features of the Constitution.

notes.title: The Himalayas
points: Fold mountains in the north.
Three parallel ranges: Himadri (Great Himalayas), Himachal (Lesser Himalayas), Shiwaliks (Outer Himalayas).
Significance: Climatic barrier, source of rivers, defense.

notes.title: The Northern Plains
points: Formed by depositional work of Indus, Ganga, Brahmaputra.
Region of rich alluvial soil, high population density, and intensive agriculture.

notes.title: The Peninsular Plateau
points: Oldest stable landmass (Gondwanaland).
divided into Central Highlands (Malwa) and Deccan Plateau.
Rich in minerals.

notes.title: Coastal Plains
points: Western Coastal Plain: Narrow, estuaries (Konkan, Kannad, Malabar).
Eastern Coastal Plain: Wide, deltas (Northern Circars, Coromandel).

notes.title: Characteristics
points: Tropical Monsoon type.
Factors: Latitude, Altitude, Distance from sea, Himalayas, Jet Streams.

notes.title: Seasons
points: Hot Weather (Summer): March to May. Loo winds.
South West Monsoon (Rainy): June to September. Arabian Sea and Bay of Bengal branches.
Retreating Monsoon: October-November. Cyclones in Odisha/Andhra.
Cold Weather (Winter): December to February. Western Disturbances cause rain in North.

realworld.title: Cherrapunji/Mawsynram
realworld.description: These places in Meghalaya record the highest rainfall in the world due to the funnel-shaped hills trapping moisture-laden winds.

notes.title: Tropical Evergreen Forests
points: Rainfall > 200 cm. Dense, trees do not shed leaves together.
Trees: Rosewood, Ebony, Mahogany.
Region: Western Ghats, North East India, Andaman & Nicobar.

notes.title: Tropical Deciduous Forests (Monsoon Forests)
points: Rainfall 100-200 cm. Shed leaves in summer to save water.
Trees: Teak, Sal, Sandalwood.
Most widespread in India.

notes.title: Littoral/Mangrove Forests
points: Found in deltas and tidal creeks.
Roots: Pneumatophores (Breathing roots).
Trees: Sundari (Sundarbans).

notes.title: Alluvial Soil
points: Transported soil by rivers.
Rich in Potash, poor in Phosphorus.
Crops: Rice, Wheat, Sugarcane.
Types: Khadar (New), Bhangar (Old).

notes.title: Black Soil (Regur)
points: Volcanic origin (Deccan Trap).
Rich in Lime, Iron; retains moisture.
Crops: Cotton, Sugarcane.

notes.title: Red Soil
points: Formed by weathering of crystalline igneous rocks.
Red colour due to iron oxide.
Crops: Millets, Pulses.

notes.title: Laterite Soil
points: Formed by Leaching (hight temp + high rain).
Acidic, poor fertility.
Crops: Tea, Coffee, Cashew.

notes.title: Water Resources
points: Importance of water: Essential for life, agriculture, industries, and maintaining ecological balance.
Sources of water: Surface water (rivers, lakes), groundwater, and rainwater.
Need for conservation: Over-exploitation, pollution, and unequal distribution require sustainable management.
Rainwater Harvesting: Method of collecting and storing rainwater for future use, reducing dependence on groundwater.
Irrigation: Artificial application of water to soil (Canal, Tank, Well, Furrow, Drip, Sprinkler).

notes.title: Forest Resources
points: Importance: Prevention of soil erosion, regulation of climate, habitat for wildlife, and source of timber/medicinal plants.
Conservation methods: Afforestation, Reforestation, Social Forestry, and checking deforestation.
Forest Cover in India: Target is 33% of geographical area (National Forest Policy, 1988).

realworld.title: Rainwater Harvesting in Tamil Nadu
realworld.description: Tamil Nadu was the first Indian state to make rainwater harvesting compulsory for all buildings to combat groundwater depletion.

realworld.title: Chipko Movement
realworld.description: A grassroots movement in the Himalayas where villagers hugged trees to prevent them from being cut down, highlighting community-led conservation.

notes.title: Types of Minerals
points: Metallic Minerals: Ferrous (Iron ore, Manganese) and Non-Ferrous (Copper, Bauxite, Gold).
Non-Metallic Minerals: Mica, Limestone.
Energy Minerals: Coal, Petroleum, Natural Gas (Conventional) and Solar, Wind, Biogas (Non-conventional).

notes.title: Iron Ore
points: Types: Magnetite (Highest quality, 70% iron), Hematite (Most important industrial ore, 50-60% iron), Limonite, Siderite.
Distribution: Odisha (Mayurbhanj, Kendujhar), Jharkhand (Singhbhum), Chhattisgarh (Bailadila), Karnataka (Kudremukh).

notes.title: Manganese
points: Uses: Manufacturing of steel (makes it tough), bleaching powder, insecticides, and batteries.
Distribution: Odisha (Largest producer), Madhya Pradesh, Karnataka.

notes.title: Bauxite
points: Use: Ore of Aluminium; lightweight, conductive, malleable.
Distribution: Odisha (Koraput, Kalahandi), Gujarat, Jharkhand.

notes.title: Coal (Black Gold)
points: Varieties: Anthracite (Best quality, >80% carbon), Bituminous (Commercial use, 60-80% carbon), Lignite (Brown coal), Peat.
Distribution: Gondwana Coal Fields (Damodar Valley - Jharia, Bokaro in Jharkhand, Raniganj in WB) and Tertiary Coal Fields (North East India).

notes.title: Petroleum (Liquid Gold)
points: Occurrence: Found in sedimentary rocks (anticlines/fault traps).
Distribution: Mumbai High (Offshore), Gujarat (Ankleshwar), Assam (Digboi - oldest field).

realworld.title: Kudremukh Mines
realworld.description: Kudremukh (Horse Face) in Karnataka is one of the largest iron ore mines in the world, exporting ore as slurry through pipelines to Mangalore port.

realworld.title: Mumbai High
realworld.description: Accounts for a significant portion of India's petroleum production, demonstrating advanced offshore drilling technology.

notes.title: Cropping Seasons
points: Kharif: Sown in June/July (Monsoon), Harvested in Sept/Oct. Crops: Rice, Maize, Cotton, Jute, Groundnut.
Rabi: Sown in Oct/Nov (Winter), Harvested in April/May. Crops: Wheat, Gram, Mustard, Barley.
Zaid: Short season between Rabi and Kharif. Crops: Watermelon, Cucumber, Vegetables.

notes.title: Major Crops
points: Rice: Staple food. Requirements: High temp (above 25°C), High humidity, Rainfall > 100cm. Areas: WB, UP, Punjab, Andhra.
Wheat: Staple in North. Requirements: Cool growing season, bright sunshine at ripening, 50-75cm rainfall. Areas: Punjab, Haryana, UP.
Millets (Coarse Grains): Jowar, Bajra, Ragi. Hardy crops, grow in dry regions.
Pulses: Gram, Tur, Urad. Leguminous crops (fix nitrogen). India is largest producer and consumer.
Sugarcane: Cash crop. Hot and humid climate (21-27°C, 75-100cm rain). India is 2nd largest producer. Areas: UP, Maharashtra.
Tea: Beverage crop. Warm, moist, frost-free climate, well-drained loamy soil (slopes). Areas: Assam, Darjeeling, Kerala.
Coffee: Arabica variety. Hot and humid, shade required. Areas: Karnataka (Baba Budan Hills), Kerala, Tamil Nadu.
Cotton: Industrial crop. High temp, light rainfall, 210 frost-free days, Black soil. Areas: Maharashtra, Gujarat.
Jute (Golden Fibre): Hot and humid, fertile floodplains. Areas: West Bengal, Bihar.

notes.title: Problems of Indian Agriculture
points: Dependence on erratic monsoon.
Small and fragmented landholdings.
Lack of modern inputs and technology in some regions.
Over-dependence on chemical fertilizers affecting soil health.

realworld.title: Green Revolution
realworld.description: Introduction of High Yielding Variety (HYV) seeds, irrigation, and fertilizers in the 1960s transformed India from food-deficient to food-surplus.

realworld.title: Organic Farming in Sikkim
realworld.description: Sikkim became India's first fully organic state, banning chemical fertilizers and pesticides to preserve potential soil health and biodiversity.

notes.title: Classification of Industries
points: Agro-based: Cotton, Jute, Sugar.
Mineral-based: Iron and Steel, Aluminium, Cement.
Public Sector (BHEL, SAIL) vs Private Sector (TISCO, Bajaj).
Basic Industries (Iron & Steel) vs Consumer Industries (Soap, Toothpaste).

notes.title: Iron and Steel Industry
points: Backbone of industrial development.
Tata Steel (TISCO): Jamshedpur. oldest, private. Raw material from nearby Odisha/Jharkhand.
Bhilai Steel Plant: Chhattisgarh (Russian collaboration).
Rourkela Steel Plant: Odisha (German collaboration).
Visakhapatnam Steel Plant: Coastal location (port advantages).

notes.title: Cotton Textile Industry
points: Largest agro-based industry.
Mumbai: 'Cottonopolis of India' due to humid climate, port, skilled labor, and market access.
Ahmedabad: 'Manchester of India'.
Coimbatore: 'Manchester of South India'.

notes.title: Information Technology (IT)
points: Knowledge-based industry.
Bengaluru (Bangalore): 'Silicon Valley of India'. Advantages: Mild climate, educational institutions, government policy.
Other hubs: Hyderabad (Cyberabad), Pune, Chennai, Gurgaon.

realworld.title: Jamshedpur Industrial City
realworld.description: Jamshedpur was chosen for TISCO due to proximity to iron ore (Noamundi), coal (Jharia), and water (Subarnarekha river), illustrating ideal industrial location factors.

realworld.title: Bengaluru IT Hub
realworld.description: The concentration of global tech giants and startups in Bengaluru drives India's software exports and economic growth.

notes.title: Mountains and Peaks
points: Himalayas: Mark the entire arc from J&K to Arunachal Pradesh.
Karakoram Range & Mt. K2 (Godwin-Austen): North of Himalayas.
Aravalli Range: Rajasthan (Oldest fold mountains).
Vindhya & Satpura Ranges: Central India, parallel to Narmada/Tapi.
Western Ghats & Eastern Ghats: Along the western and eastern coasts.
Nilgiri Hills: Junction of Western and Eastern Ghats.
Mt. Kanchenjunga: Sikkim/Nepal border.
Garo, Khasi, Jaintia Hills: Meghalaya (Heavy rainfall region).

notes.title: Plateaus and Plains
points: Deccan Plateau: Triangular landmass south of Narmada.
Chota Nagpur Plateau: Mineral-rich region (Jharkhand/WB).
Gangetic Plains: Fertile plains of North India.
Coastal Plains: Konkan, Malabar (West); Coromandel, Northern Circars (East).

notes.title: Water Bodies
points: Arabian Sea (West), Bay of Bengal (East), Indian Ocean (South).
Gulf of Kutch & Gulf of Khambhat: Gujarat coast.
Palk Strait/Gulf of Mannar: Between India and Sri Lanka.
Chilika Lake (Odisha), Wular Lake (J&K).

realworld.title: Strategic Importance of Palk Strait
realworld.description: Palk Strait creates a narrow channel separating India and Sri Lanka, a critical maritime checkpoint.

realworld.title: Aravallis and Rainfall
realworld.description: The Aravallis run parallel to the Arabian Sea branch of monsoons, causing no obstruction and leading to minimal rainfall in Rajasthan.

notes.title: Himalayan Rivers
points: Indus: Flows through Ladakh into Pakistan.
Jhelum, Chenab, Ravi, Beas, Sutlej: Tributaries of Indus (Punjab).
Ganga: Originates from Gangotri, flows eastwards.
Yamuna: Important tributary of Ganga.
Brahmaputra: Enters Arunachal (Dihang), flows through Assam.

notes.title: Peninsular Rivers
points: Narmada & Tapi: West flowing rivers, flow in rift valleys.
Mahanadi: Flows through Odisha (Hirakud Dam).
Godavari: Dakshin Ganga, longest peninsular river.
Krishna & Tungabhadra: Flow eastwards.
Kaveri: Southernmost major river.

notes.title: Passes
points: Karakoram Pass: J&K (Ladakh).
Nathu La: Sikkim (Trade route to China).
Palghat Gap: Western Ghats (Kerala-Tamil Nadu).

realworld.title: River Interlinking
realworld.description: Proposals to link Himalayan and Peninsular rivers to manage drought and flood situations effectively.

realworld.title: Narmada Rift Valley
realworld.description: Narmada flows through a rift valley between the Vindhya and Satpura ranges, unlike most other Indian rivers.

notes.title: Soil Distribution
points: Alluvial Soil: Indo-Gangetic plains, Coastal deltas (Most fertile).
Black Soil (Regur): Deccan trap (Maharashtra, Gujarat, MP) - Good for Cotton.
Red Soil: Periphery of Deccan Plateau (Iron rich, less fertile).
Laterite Soil: High leaching areas (Western Ghats summits, Meghalaya).

notes.title: Crop Production Areas
points: Rice: West Bengal, Andhra Pradesh coasts.
Wheat: Punjab, Haryana, UP.
Cotton: Maharashtra (Black soil belt), Gujarat.
Jute: West Bengal (Hugli basin).
Tea: Assam, Nilgiris.
Coffee: Karnataka (Coorg/Chikmagalur).
Sugarcane: Uttar Pradesh, Maharashtra.

realworld.title: Black Soil and Cotton
realworld.description: The moisture-retentive capacity of Black Soil makes it ideal for rain-fed cotton cultivation in the Deccan region.

notes.title: Mineral Distribution (Map)
points: Iron Ore: Singhbhum (Jharkhand), Mayurbhanj (Odisha).
Coal: Jharia (Jharkhand), Raniganj (WB).
Oil Fields: Digboi (Assam), Mumbai High (Arabian Sea).

notes.title: Industrial Centres (Map)
points: Steel Plants: Jamshedpur (TISCO), Bhilai, Visakhapatnam.
Cotton Textile: Mumbai, Ahmedabad.
Electronic City: Bengaluru.
Automobile: Chennai (Detroit of India), Gurgaon.

notes.title: Population Density (Map)
points: Densely Populated: Gangetic Plains, Kerala Coast.
Sparsely Populated: Thar Desert, North-Eastern Hills, Ladakh.

realworld.title: Mumbai High Location
realworld.description: Located approx 160km off the coast of Mumbai, it is India's largest oil field and requires specific map identification.

realworld.title: Chota Nagpur Plateau
realworld.description: Often called the 'Ruhr of India' due to its rich concentration of minerals like coal, iron ore, and mica.
